Spain is one country that is using the term `marriage' to talk about gay partnerships.
The country approved these partnerships in June despite opposition from the Catholic Church.
Joining us now to talk about the situation there is Jerome Socolovsky, a freelance reporter who's heard often here on NPR.
He's with us from Madrid.
Nice of you to join us today.
Good to be with you, Neal.
So it is gay marriage, same as heterosexual marriage in Spain?
It is.
I believe it would be classified under the first model mentioned by Professor Wintemute.

It's classified even with the term `matrimonio,' or `matrimony,' which has a religious connotation for many Catholics in Spain, and that's what the church was very much upset about, that the government gave it that name.

Even opponents, even the Conservative Party, which was against the legislation here, was willing--many of the people in the party were willing to accept some kind of civil union or some sort of an arrangement that's similar to what Britain is doing, but they didn't want an equal status with a union between a man and a woman.
For Spain, obviously, for many, many, many years, Catholicism was the official religion.
That's no longer the case.
Well, it's a huge leap for Spain.
If you do think back before 1975, the year that the Spanish dictator Francisco Franco, died--before then, gays could be thrown in jail, and since then, things have changed.
But this is a real culmination for a lot of homosexuals here.
The church has said--some of the cardinals there have said that those who perform such services should consider their conscience and not do it.
Indeed.

Before the law was enacted, or before it was even passed in Parliament, the church called on mayors, on civil servants who would perform marriages--called on them to say--or to cite conscientious objection, which is part of the law here.
And there's been quite a debate about that, which is continuing even today.
There are certain judges--there are judges who perform marriages, and some places that mayors do it.
And several have refused to.
One, in particular, has made a legal case citing conscientious objection.

Now the government says you can't cite conscientious objection, in this case because that would be like saying, `I refuse to marry people of different colors or different races or different ethnic groups,' which would be a clear form of discrimination here.

But at the same time, this is an issue here that the right knows it cannot win.
A lot of people associate restriction, any kind of restrictions, on homosexuality with what happened during the dictatorship.
